Kingdom East Families: WE WANT TO HEAR FROM YOU!
How can we best meet your needs remotely this fall? Please complete this ONE-question survey by clicking the link here:

https://forms.gle/iy5QrEEdXvbHhwNd7

Due to low staff numbers, including those in key site leadership roles, the Afterschool Program will be offering remote programming for Session 1 for students in grades K-8. Starting in late September, KEAP opportunities will include online enrichment classes, take-home enrichment kits, and phone/online homework help. There will be no in-person KEAP programs at the schools in September or October. We plan to offer in-person programming starting in Session 2 (after Thanksgiving) when we are confident that we have staff members in place to safely manage Covid-19 precautions and safely logistics.

Kelly Walsh

A note today about registration for the Fall semester 2020

You should be receiving documents from your school asking for enrollment information. We collect this information at the Pre School and Elementary School level in order to plan for class size and to give teachers an idea about what their duties will be for the fall. We are planners!

At the High School level we collect residency information so that when we receive money from the state to pay for high school tuition it can be dispersed accurately for the students who live in our towns.

Take note this week. Check your snail mail and your email. Lets get all this paperwork done early!!!!! Thank you for your help!

The 7th Grade Water For All Exhibition was held yesterday! After six full weeks of research, learning and teamwork, the 7th graders displayed their proposed solutions for 8 different global locations: Mexico, India, South Africa, Morocco, Chile, Qatar, Australia and West Burke.

The solutions ranged from improved infrastructure, to installing fog harvesters, to vertical farming. Students talked about what water is, why it is an essential resource for humans, and why it is a dwindling resource.

Thank you to the community members and families who came to the exhibition!

The annual Mentor Mentee Dinner was held Wednesday May 29th at the Lyndon Outing Club. Each spring, after a year of teaching, mentors and mentees gather together to break bread, enjoy a meal and share the growth and learning that occurred during the school year. The Kingdom East School District's unique mentoring program provides every teacher new to the profession a confidential, supportive individual whom they can use as a resource and support system. The mentor guides the new teacher and helps him or her walk through the school year. To learn more about this program please reach out to Theresa Young our Director of Innovation and Learning, and also review the program handbook.

The mentor program helps mentees hone their craft and provide the best quality education possible to our children! Congratulations to all of our new teachers and a hearty thank you to Katie Scanlon and Rachel Robillard who co-directed the program, and of course thank you to all of our mentors.
